text: (upbeat music)
- Siladitya, welcome to the show.

- Thanks Ismail. Thanks
for the opportunity.
Glad to be here.
- Looking forward to hearing your views

on the current data
trends, but before that,

can you give us a brief about
who you are and what you do?
- Yeah, sure. Absolutely.
So I'm Sil.
I am a senior principal in the data
and technology practice in Slalom.
So just a quick thing of who Slalom are.

So we are a purpose led business
and tech consulting firm.

And the most unique thing that
we do about it is anything
that we do is very human centric.
So data, technology, process, business,
we do with a human focus.

That's who we are and that's
how we do all the projects

with our different
partners and organizations.
- So in your experience with Slalom,
you guys have been implementing data
and AI projects hands-on with customers
in the UK and and around the world?
- Yeah, so just like I said,
like even though we are global firm,
my personal focus is being on UK AI.
So we work with a few partners of us
and from strategy to implementation,

we do lots of data and
technology projects.

- So in the last few years,
the concept of a data mesh
has gained a lot of traction.

Could you explain to us, you
know, what is a data mesh
and why is it so popular?
- Yeah, absolutely.
That's a very good question, Ismail.

So like, because we have
been speaking to a lot

of organizations in the past
few years, like you said,

and before, like you said,
gen AI picked up the hype,
data mesh used to be the next big thing.

So yes, people want to
get into a data mesh.
Everyone thinks it's a silver bullet.

So there are some partners of
us who want to do data mesh

because they think it's,
they have heard about it,
they think it's a good thing.

Some partners who have seen
their peers today data mesh
and they want to jump on the bandwagon.

So yes, we do get a lot
of questions on data mesh.

So in a very simplistic way
it's like make data available
for all and almost get the data divide,
like there should not be any data divide.

So everyone should have
access to the data.

That's what the data
mesh tries to accomplish.
Whether they do it or not,

that's probably an altogether
different question.
- Right, and it's supposed to be aligned
to different business domains.
- Absolutely.
- Okay.

But I mean domain driven
designs been around for a while.

Is this really something new?
What's different about it?

- Yeah, like we have been
doing domain driven design
since the late 1990s, early 2000s.
- Okay.

- So if you think like when
you start with any problem
or any business problem,
because that's where we always start,

we start with the problem
that we need to solve

rather than what technology
we need to implement.
That's our starting point.

So things like your event
storming, like you, when you go

and work with a partner, you
sort of capture all the events,

all the business processes,
then you sort of put them
into one big whiteboard.

It used to be a physical
whiteboard before COVID hit.
Since then it is being all virtual.

But at the end of the
day you'll still put it
on one big whiteboard.

You sort of map all
the business processes,

then you come to the
attributes and design.

So you almost like capture
the whole business process

in different domains so that
everyone within the business,

they speak the common language,
so that when I say patient,

and you say care subject,
we both mean the same thing,

if you're talking about
healthcare as an example.
So that's what domain driven design does.

And then when you flip
it to a data product,

that's the next thing which
the domain driven design
did not do is package it as a product
and then sell it to the consumers.

That's where the next trend
is happening at the moment.
- So you just mentioned data product.
Is that different from a data mesh?
Like what is it and-
- It's not different from a data mesh.

It is sort of a
constituent to a data mesh.
But then you could have-
- It's a part of-

- Like you could say
it's a part of data mesh

because to implement a data
mesh you need a data product.
But then you could also have data product
without implementing data mesh.

So data mesh could not
live with a data product,

but the data product could
live with a data mesh.
- Can you unpack that a little bit?
Like what's the, when would you have
this one and not that one?
- Absolutely. Yeah.

So I'll probably start
with a simple example.
- Sure.

- Like how often in
your life have you sort
of said at the time like, wish I knew,
like wish I knew this existed.

I could have, it would've
made my life easy.
- Yeah, a lot.
- Exactly. Yeah.

Yeah, so like I was working
with a partner of ours
and we sort created a nice dashboard.

And then six months down
the line when we worked

with another department
with the same partner,

they wanted something
similar and we said like,

did you know like your
colleagues had already

done something similar that
could be useful to you?
And they said the same thing, wish I knew.

So that's the question that
data products tends to solve.
So when you call a data product,

there are few things which
are sort of features.

So first thing is like
the discoverability,

like for something to
exist you have to know.

So you have to make it
available to everyone.
It should be easily accessible
so that everyone has got access
and everyone knows what it means.

We did touch upon the
domain-driven design,
so everyone speaks a common language.

So you have a data product,
you make it accessible

to everyone, it should
also give you some value
and you should trust the data.

So all these things are
like a data product.
It could be simple as a dashboard,
it could be simple as an API.
It could be simple as a microservice.
So they all could be a data product.
But for something as a dashboard

to be called a data product,
it should be like accessible,
discoverable, trustworthy, and something
that gives value to you,

'cause without the value
it doesn't make any sense
to create a product.
- So based on what you're saying,

it seems like data mesh is a
way of democratizing access

and creation of data
across the organization,
whereas a data product doesn't require
a data mesh necessarily.
It's just building something

that would be accessible,
discoverable to other users.

So you could build a
data product while being

a centralized team or you
could build a data product
through a data mesh by being centralized.
So they're related in the sense

that the data mesh
could allow the creation

of data products bottom up
instead of being, you know,
top down or centralized.

But that's not necessarily
prerequisite for it.

- Yeah, that's a very good
point because you did mention
one key word called centralized.
So what data mesh does

and what we are sort
of been advocating too

with our partners is like yes
you need to have a central
sort of a CEO or a governance group
which sort of will set the rules.

But then to create a
data product you should
have like a hybrid model.

So you enable people to
create the data products
but you don't almost handhold them.

You sort of give them
the tools, the process,
the means to create a product.

In that way you can sort of
scale faster without being

a single point bottleneck,
which we have seen
happen in some places.
- Okay.

- So probably move from a
centralized to a hybrid model.

- So it's a way of
scaling out the creation
of data products.
- Yeah, exactly.

- So how have organizations
been applying this concept

of building a data
product to their benefit?
- That's a good question.

Like again, I'll probably
take the example that we sort
of touched upon a bit earlier,

like we call like a
patient and a care subject.

Again, when I used to work with
a healthcare client of ours,
like there were like different systems,
applications spread all over.

Some systems had sort of a
unique ID called the patient ID,

whereas others they had a key,
they meant the same thing.
But because there was no way of knowing

that they meant the same
thing, there was no way

of linking it up and
creating sort of a dashboard
that showed everything in one place.

So we talked about the
domain driven design,

that helps you to create
that common language,

create that sort of
single version of truth
that everyone can understand.

That's like the step one that
helps organizations a lot.

We did touch upon, when you
talk about data products,
we made it discoverable.

For you to sort of create
something new, you have to know

what already exists and if
you can sort of reuse it,

use it to accelerate your
journey, that helps your journey.
So that's the two ways that we have seen.
And again, the scalability,

because now we are able to
decouple a small use case,

show the value, gone are
the days when people used
to wait a year and a half
to create a data warehousing project.
You have to show value now
and it's like you show value like then.

So you can almost decouple your
use case, create a product,
show the value, like get the sponsors sort
of all on board and then scale it up.

That's where we are seeing
it's rebuilding value.

Like start small, fail
fast, show the value
and then sort of scale it up quickly.

- And what are some of the
common challenges we see

in organizations that are trying
to implement data products
and what advice would you give them?

- Like data governance
probably ranks number one.

Like it's always good to say
that, yes, I want to sort
of implement a data mesh.
It's always good to say that yes I want

to create a data product, but
then the first question we ask

our partner organization is
like, do you know what you have?
And the answer nine out of 10 times is no.

So creating a data catalog,
whether it's a business catalog

or data catalog, even you
even a simple SharePoint
is better than having nothing.

So you can obviously get
a tool off the market,

but having a simple
SharePoint, if you have nothing
that's like step number one.
And then having the roles and access,

like who's the steward,
who's gonna govern the data,

the data owner, that sort of
data governance and management,
that's probably missing,

and that's probably the like
step number one for any,
whether you do a mesh or a product,
that's probably step number one.
And it's very funny to say

that we always start a
conversation with a data mesh,

but we end up agreeing that yes
I need data governance first
before we can even go there.
So I would say that's number one.

And then once you do it, it's
like no partner organization
(indistinct) like a clean green field.
Like you always have some technical depth,
some technologies already in use.

So it's always good to make
use of things you already have

because you also have
the people with skills.
Like upskilling someone with a new tool
might be difficult whereas using the skill
that they already have might be easier.

So we always sort of
nudge them towards that.
Like use the skills you have,
build something that shows value
and then you can always scale it up.
- So how do you square that circle?
I mean on the one hand,
data governance is the main challenge
for building out data products.

On the other hand we wanna be
able to iterate and fail fast

and fail forward like you
were mentioning before,
prove the value quickly.

How would you advise organizations
balance these two things?

- I think that the way
that we normally advise

and how we work with the
partners is like we start small.

Like you probably take one
department or a sub-department
or maybe a business process.

You do all the things
that you just mentioned,
show the value.

Say like if you sort of
take a small department
within a sort of organization

and you show the value like,
okay, this dashboard used
to take days, now it takes minutes.
That's the value you show to them.
And once you show the value
and then you can bring people on board

because end of the day
you have to like enhance

the data culture of
the whole organization.
That's what you are aiming for.

Because like every good
thing, people, process,

and technology, you can
have the best technology

if you have the money, you can
always agree on the process,

but then it's people who
are gonna make it happen.

So that's where you need
to have the data culture.

So start small, showcase
it, do the roadshows

and everything you need
to do, bring the value in

so that you get more
people on board the journey

and then it becomes very
easy to scale it up.
- So really the business value is the key

for overcoming the governance
challenges as well?
Not just the implementation challenges
of the project itself.
- Exactly.
Because like whenever you do a,

or whenever you start a
data governance thing,
you always have some roles
as data steward and data owners.
- Yeah.

- And if I come and
tell you, Ismail, like,

that's a new role that now
you're being given too,

which means, okay, I have to
now spend extra four hours

of my day to do the job, you
will obviously not be happy.
- Yeah.

- But then if I can justify
why you're gonna spend

the role is going to make
everyone's life better,
then you might be inclined to do it.
So that's how we show the value to people.

Like this is what you
do and that's the value

that it brings to you and
the whole organization,

and that's why we bring
everybody on board.
- That makes a lot of sense.

And I think that showing
the business value
from the top line is definitely key here.

But also the other part
of it is making sure
that the use case is small enough
or easy enough to implement.
And a thought comes to mind that you know,

it means that the success
of these projects will be,

will depend a lot on
how easy it is for each

of these use cases to
get out the door quick.
And one way to reduce friction

would be to use gen
AI, for example, right.
So what are the different ways

that organizations
could use gen AI to kind
of help build out data products?
- That's a great question.

You actually like meshed
the two hype things

that are going on the market,
like gen AI and data products.

So I think they're like, the
way that I would probably
split the question is like two hubs.
One is like how would you use gen AI
to implement a data product,

and then probably using gen
AI to build a data product.
Like I said, like anything that we do
in a product world has to have a value.

So writing out the value
proposition statement

is probably one of the
things that we have to do.
And gen AI or something like ChatGPT
makes our life very easy.
We can easily do it with very low,
like with very less time.
Second thing is like if you had to write

like a low code or no
code thing like that,

that's very easy to do
with the gen AI so that you
can get a sort of simple quick code out
of the door very easily,
and then you can sort of see the value,
always iterate and scale it up.

That's the two ways we
see then sort of gen AI
bringing value to how you could accelerate
your journey, data products.

And just to give an example,
like one of the things

that we did with one of
our clients in the US
was Virgin, now we all know that chatbots
is something that's not new.
It's been like for last 10 years maybe.

But then the thing that that
we built with them is a chatbot

that's empathetic to you,
which means that it'll respond
to you as a user, how you're feeling.
So if you're sad or like you're happy,
it would respond to you accordingly.
And because it can then go

and sort of go into its
own knowledge database,

the concerns of data privacy,
all that do not exist
because it's not going to the wide world
to get all the knowledge.
It's always limited.
So that's how we would use gen AI

to build a data product
that's actually very useful.
So it could be as simple as a chat bot,
but then the way that you sort of,

and always like we have been
using Alexa in our daily lives.
So the way that Alexa responds

and learns about you, that's
a lot of gen AI in it.
So that's the product we have been,

or most of us have been
using (indistinct),
that's the product with gen AI.

- So what about how gen AI
can help with the people
that are working on these projects?
Can it enhance productivity somehow?

- Well absolutely, like I mean
simple thing like you getting

the minutes outta the meeting
could be done by a gen AI.

Simple thing like you
getting a, like coding,

the basic coding done, that
could be done with the gen AI.
Like simple things like getting

if you're going for a low code

those things like which you probably
spent some time doing it,

those things can be now done
to accelerate the journey.

You don't spend so much
time so that your time
to market becomes a lot less.

So these are the sort
of the different ways
that we have seen gen AI helping people,
us developers and coders,
to sort of bring value to our clients
or to automations much faster.

- So what can accelerate things
on maybe the internal side
or on the engineering side.
What about the customer success side?
Is there a part to play
for improving the customer experience?
- Yeah, absolutely.

So again, like when you
talk of customer success,
one thing that comes to my mind
is sort of a master data management
or customer 360.
Now we have all worked with our-
- What is customer 360?

- Oh customer 360 is
like having the full view
of your customer.

So if you're a retail
client, you would want
to know all about your customer.
If you are in healthcare,

you would want to know
all about your patient.
It's underlying same concept,
but like from an industry term,
we call it customer 360.
- So it's like a unified profile
of your customer, patient, citizen-
- Whatever, patient, citizen.

And like one thing that
we have built with AWS
is the fan data platform.

So because we worked with one
of the premier league clubs

in Northwest we saw there
was like lot of value
in knowing the single view of the fan.

And because they were like
different ticketing systems

and it was very difficult
to learn like okay,
if I bought a ticket on system A
and tomorrow I go to system B

and buy a ticket, it's very
difficult to merge them.
Like they didn't have the process.

So what we did is like
build an application
that puts all the data in one place

so that I know about
you a smile like, okay,
I bought four tickets in a year,
but then you might also take your son
to a football coaching camp.
How do I connect that data with this data
which helps me to get the complete picture
of you probably as a household.

Then you might be buying
insurance from someone else.

Like is it worth me
selling something to you?
Can I use the data?
So yes you can do it

but then to do it you need
to have the complete picture
of me as a fan, like you said,
a citizen or a customer or a patient.

So that's something I
think is really very good
and that's something where we have
actually helped our partner organizations.
- So with this fan 360 scenario,

not only do you have the
different data about each fan

and the touch points
that they've interacted

with your brand, you also
have their connections

and relationships to other
fans or potential fans,

and together, that
surfaces new insights about

that household like you said,
which is a relationship,

or let's say a group of
relationships together,
which brings new customer experiences

that you couldn't have done
for an individual thing.
- Absolutely, absolutely.
And I think what we have also done
is we have taken a bit further and say,
like if I am a fan of a football club,

I don't wanna name any, but
then if I'm fan of football club

and then I go for a
champions league match,

say in Berlin, like I would
need to book my travel,
I would need to book my hotel,
and if I'm in Berlin from UK,

I would probably spend a
day doing a SaaS AI thing.
Can I sell that as a complete package?

So those are things
which will give you sort

of additional revenues to
like the football club.

So it's not just the
money you get from ticket,

but the money you get from
selling that whole package,

from going for a champions
match in some other places.
That's where we see the value back
to our partners organizations
of having that single view of a fan.

- So the situations
where you've built this,

what was the actual business
value that the organization

that you worked, like for
the fan data platform?

- So for the fan data, like
I mentioned like, there was,

they did not have a
single view of the fan.
So they had like individual systems
and they got the individual information.
So there was no way to connect

or no way to know that, whether
you have bought four tickets

in a year and you are
only interested in going
for a champions league match,

or you are only going
for the home matches.

There was no way of
getting that information.

So the value was like
getting to know the fan,
what he or she liked, which matches,

and then simple things like
if I've given you my address
while registering my account,
I know where you're traveling from.
I could also advise you on the travel
if there are like problems or roadblocks,

something, like I can even
advise you on the travel.
There are access rate issues.

I can advise you on the right
gate to enter the stadium.
Things could be very simple.
- Sure.

- It doesn't have to
be revenue generating,

but it's all to enhance your
experience when you come
to a stadium.
That's what they were aiming for.

- Right, so it can
either reduce retention,
sorry, improve retention,
or improve customer satisfaction,
have more repeat purchases,
for example, all of those different-
- Exactly. Yeah, like you said.

- So you talked about a lot
of different concepts today,

data mesh, data products,
customer 360, it's a lot.

With the technology landscape
evolving so rapidly,
how do we stay up to date?
- That's a very good question, Ismail.
So the one thing that I try to follow
in my own personal life is to be curious.

So I try to read about
the different technology,

things that are happening
all over the world.

But then I think one thing which
we also advise our partners

and organizations is like to
be a business technologist,

which means you have got
one eye on the business
because that's your why.
Why am I going to do certain things?
That's your business problem.
And then how you do it,
that's the technology part.
You always start with the why

and then you find out what
are the different ways

that this can be done in
the most efficient way.

So if you sort of try to
be a business technologist,

then you probably will be
able to sort of keep abreast

of all things that are
happening around you.
- So I think that's a great way

to go about it from a
personal perspective.
What about organizations?
How can organizations as a whole,
instead of just being bogged down
by their business operations keep ahead
of the curve when it comes to technology?
- That's a good question, Ismail.
Like, within Slalom,

the engine I work for,
we have got a framework
called the Modern Culture of Data.
What it essentially means is, yes,

we have got the business
strategy, we always start
with the business strategy because that's
where every problem needs to be solved.
That's where you define the problems.
And then we talk about the small uses,
the big use cases, that's where we start.

Then we sort of, once the
business strategy is done,

we then go onto the
technology side of things.

So the modern culture of
data actually gives you
that whole framework from business
to the strategy to the implementation.

Whether it be the gen
AI, the data governance,

the data privacy,
everything's covered there.
So that's like one single package which we
can offer to the clients.

It's a framework, and
then based on your needs,
we can always flex the framework
and make it suitable for you.
- Right, and so the benefit of a framework

is that they can make it
a part of their business,
and hopefully, a part of their culture
so that they become business technologists
like you mentioned by design.
- Yeah, absolutely.
And like this is a framework
that's not being like framed today.

I mean it has been with
Slalom for a few years,

which means we have got
many client stories.

What's worked for them,
what's not worked for them.
We are always iterating the framework

and we can also share
the stories that, okay,
this problem looks similar
to something we have done two years back,

even though it might be
from the same industry,
different industry, doesn't really matter,
the problem could be similar.
And that's where we can also help you.
Like if that's worked good for them,

it might be useful for you,
like maybe you have a think.
So it's not just a framework

but also loads of experience
that that we bring with it.

- So bringing it all back
together, if I was a CDO
who just started in their organization

and I have 60 to 90 days
to make something happen,

what would you advise the first
few steps for me should be.
- Good question again.
So if you had only 60 to 90 days to do it,

I would probably start
with the holistic view
of what are my immediate problems
and what are my long-term goals.

Once I have the list, then
probably narrow it down
to the three to five things that I need

to achieve in the next
one month, two months,
30 to 60 days.
And again, like we said, start small,

show the value and then
you can scale it up.
So always start with a big list.
Maybe the long term goals.
I would achieve this in two years time,

but then always have that
eye on the short term goal,

and then always narrow down
your use cases to three to five
because if you have more than five,
you're probably not going to achieve it
or you're gonna spread too thin.
So have it small, focus on them,

show the value, and then
you can always scale it up.

- Okay, so think big,
start small, iterate.
Great.
Thank you so much, Siladitya.
It was great having you.
- It's a pleasure here. Thanks.
